abstracts.cdata!:
The panel rated the supervision of this
            Second Community Water and Sanitation Project for Ghana as
            highly satisfactory with the two subcategories - focus on
            development effectiveness and adequacy of supervision inputs
            and processes - also rated highly satisfactory. The project
            became effective on 7/19/2000, almost eleven month after
            Board presentation. This was the major initial problem. The
            two effectiveness conditions, which took a long time to be
            resolved, were: (i) the nomination of the Central Water
            Sanitation Agency (CWSA) Board, and (ii) Parliamentary
            approval of the subsidiary grant agreement between the
            Government and CWSA. There was a close follow up of the
            effectiveness issue by the Bank through the resident mission
            and the 2000 CPPR was instrumental in raising to the
            attention of Government of Ghana (GOG) senior managers the
            urgency of obtaining Parliamentary approval for all pending
            subsidiary grants agreement under Bank credits. With regard
            to the issue of harmonization of the water supply/sanitation
            policies, the Bank team has been very proactive in reaching
            out to other donors with a view to convince them to adopt a
            common sector wide approach, and progress is being made.
            Conditions for effectiveness have to be strictly minimized
            and reduced to the legal opinion and the signing of
            subsidiary agreements, if and when applicable. In this case,
            delay could have been reduced if the nomination of the Board
            could have been made a condition of Board presentation.
